comment.text: Catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate (OAA) to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP), the rate-limiting step in the metabolic pathway that produces glucose from lactate and other precursors derived from the citric acid cycle.
Enzyme activity is enhanced by acetylation.
Major sites of expression are liver, kidney and adipocytes.
Lysine acetylation by p300/EP300 is increased on high glucose conditions and promotes ubiquitination by UBR5, acetylation is enhanced in the presence of BAG6. Deacetylated by SIRT2.
Ubiquitination by UBR5 leads to proteasomal degradation.

disease.name: Cytosolic phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase deficiency
disease.description: Metabolic disorder resulting from impaired gluconeogenesis. It is a rare disease with less than 10 cases reported in the literature. Clinical characteristics include hypotonia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, lactic acidosis and hypoglycemia. Autopsy reveals fatty infiltration of both the liver and kidneys. The disorder is transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
In eukaryotes there are two isozymes: a cytoplasmic one and a mitochondrial one.
Belongs to the phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase [GTP] family.

property.value: Transcriptional regulation of white adipocyte differentiation
P:cellular response to potassium ion starvation
P:cellular response to tumor necrosis factor
P:positive regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter in response to acidic pH
